title: RL34102
content: Both chambers of Congress passed legislation to reauthorize FDA programs and expand its authority for medical product safety. The bills, S. 1082 and H.R. 2900, renew FDA's authority for key user fee programs set to expire in FY2007. FDA urged Congress to complete reauthorization efforts before August 1, 2007. The FDA faced funding uncertainty leading to a hiring freeze and potential layoffs due to the expiration of key user fee programs. The bills S. 1082 and H.R. 2900 aimed to reauthorize FDA programs and address concerns related to pediatric pharmaceuticals. This report compares S. 1082 and H.R. 2900, focusing on differences in prescription drug user fees, medical device regulation, pediatric incentives, drug safety, clinical trials, conflicts of interest, and other provisions amending FDA's authorities. The bills aim to reauthorize FDA programs and address pediatric pharmaceutical concerns. The report compares S. 1082 and H.R. 2900, focusing on differences in prescription drug user fees, medical device regulation, pediatric incentives, drug safety, clinical trials, conflicts of interest, and other provisions amending FDA's authorities. The bills aim to reauthorize FDA programs and address pediatric pharmaceutical concerns. For background information on the impetus for this legislation and an overview of the two bills, refer to CRS Report RL34089.
